metadata.title: Potential mechanisms of unintended population health impacts from strict social distancing and recommendations for mitigation

abstract.text: This table uses Scotland as a case study to assess the nature and scale of the potential impacts and suggest recommendations. Figures given are for Scotland, with a total population of 5 million, or UK which has a total population of 66 million people.

body_text.text: People in precarious employment, on zero hours contracts or self employed Estimated 1.87million people without access to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) 1 in the UK although this may underestimate the problem if SSP is not available during self-isolation Loss of all income: for 7 days for those with mild illness or isolation only; for 14-21 days for those with more severe illness. This is likely to have markedly negative physical and mental health impacts 2 3 High impact disproportionately affecting younger, women and their dependents, and amongst the already low paid Immediate sickness benefits (at a minimum at SSP levels) for ill people or who are asked to selfisolate, including people who are self-employed or do not meet the criteria for SSP currently Workers for whom the demand for their labour reduces as a direct or indirect consequence of restrictive social distancing Workers in industries most affected by the response to the pandemic (tourism, hospitality, entertainment, sport, transport, self-employed, small/medium enterprises, etc.)

Uncertain number affected as this will depend on the degree of recessionary effect and the particular sectors involved. Could include all but the most 'essential' of sectors (e.g. health/social care, utilities, food chain) but difficult to define the limits to this Unemployment is known to have large negative impacts on mental health 4 and some causes of mortality 5 ; however, the general recessionary effects on population health are more mixed 6 7 and are discussed below High impact, disproportionately affecting those of working age and their dependents Provide easily accessible incomes for all affected people. Abolish five week wait for UC. Implement minimum income guarantee or basic income at a level equivalent to minimum income for healthy living. Provide advice that allows people to continue working safely when physical distance can be maintained. Workers whose workplace is closed temporarily to achieve social distancing Workers in affected industries which do not continue to provide pay during that period (i.e. people in precarious employment, on zero hours contracts or self employed) Uncertain number affected as this will depend on the degree of closure and the particular sectors involved. Could include all but the most 'essential' of sectors (e.g. health/social care, food chain) for some period of time, but difficult to define the limits to this (e.g. the need for transport to continue, IT support, etc.) Loss of income for affected workers is likely to have markedly negative physical and mental health impacts 2 3 High impact, disproportionately affecting younger, female adults and their dependents, and amongst the already low paid Provide easily accessible incomes for all affected people
Workers who have to reduce their work because of caring responsibilities
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Working age adults with children and elderly relatives, particularly women
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Uncertain number depending on the course of the pandemic (i.e. the number of people who are ill and require care at any one time)
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Loss of income for affected workers is likely to have markedly negative physical and mental health impacts 2 3 High impact, disproportionately affecting younger, female adults and their dependents, and amongst the already low paid
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Provide an immediately accessible carers benefit for those without paid carers leave and bring this in line with the minimum income for healthy living. Social security claimants who are not able to demonstrate meeting associated conditions Some claimants of Universal Credit and legacy benefits 2.8m people in the UK were on the conditional form of Universal Credit in January 2020 8 -the number who may be at risk of breaking conditions due to the pandemic or the response will be substantially lower Loss of income for affected people is likely to have markedly negative physical and mental health impacts 2 3 High impact, disproportionately affecting those who are on low incomes and have pre-existing health conditions Suspend conditionality on all currently received benefits. Suspend further migration (natural or planned) to Universal Credit for existing claimants too to avoid adding to income disruption. Suspend recovery of historic public sector debt repayments (e.g. tax credits). Income insecurity may result in risks to maintaining housing Those living in rented housing or with an outstanding mortgage, who might be affected by any of the above forms of income shocks 4.5m households were in private rental accommodation in 2017; 9 there were around 5m households in social rented accommodation in 2018, 10 and there are a further 9.2m households with outstanding property debts (the majority of which will be mortgages). 11 It is difficult to accurately quantify the number who are likely to be affected by the above income shocks. However, it is likely to be substantial.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Actual loss of housing has substantial impacts on health, but even the threat of housing insecurity is likely to have adverse impacts on mental health and probably also on physical health and its determinants.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: High impact, disproportionately affecting those on low incomes and younger households.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Introduce measures to suspend rental and mortgage payments, evictions, and take the actions detailed above to address income insecurity (including mortgage and rent payment suspension for both private and social landlords). Extend Scottish Options of maintaining housing benefit direct to landlord to England and Wales. Monitor the impact of replacing Support for Mortgage Interest (SMI) with a loan.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Economic recession The groups most frequently adversely affected are those in low paid and precarious work This is dependent on the severity and length of any recessionary impact.
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: The impacts of recession on health are mixed and not necessarily negative overall. Error! Bookmark not defined. 7 Improvements occur through lower mortality from road-traffic accidents and alcohol-related causes but suicide and mental health problems increase.
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Mixed impacts with mental health problems being the greatest risk
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: The recommendations in this area relate to supporting people's incomes (as per the rows above) and mental health (as per the rows below)
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Longer term failure of businesses with loss of employment and income Workers in industries most affected by the response to the pandemic (tourism, hospitality, entertainment, sport, transport, self-employed, small/medium enterprises, etc.)
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Very uncertain and dependent on the depth and length of any recession and the effectiveness of economic mitigation measures
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: The direct impacts of reduced employment and income over the long-term will disproportionately affect the working age population through poorer mental health and increased mortality. The longterm impacts of the 1980s recession and the associated restructuring of the economy caused substantial excess mortality and morbidity. 12 This is uncertain but could be substantial.
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: In addition the recommendations elsewhere, consider opportunities to retrain the workforce into more sustainable and growth areas of the economy (e.g. care sector, refitting of heating systems).
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Falling value of pensions assets Pensioners -people of pensionable age dependent on private pensions, those who are soon to move into pensionable age and those currently of working age whose pension value will be reduced in the future. This will impact most on higher income groups who are much more likely to have private pension wealth. 13
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: In the long-run this will affect everybody with a private pension (estimated at 53% of the population 13 ), but this will have particular short-run impacts on those close to retirement age or currently dependent on private pensions.
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: There will lower incomes from pensions in the medium to long run, but state pension payments will continue and avoid people moving to zero income. The impacts are therefore likely to be modest although some people currently on higher incomes may notice large decreases in the medium to long-run.
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: The impact is likely to be greater in the medium to longrun and for those already in receipt of higher incomes
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Ensure that state pensions are not eroded in the coming period to provide a minimum income for this group
body_text.section: Macroeconomic consequences

body_text.text: Reduced government revenue This depends on how governments react to lower revenues. If an austerity approach is taken to balance the public finances this will impact on public services, public sector employment and social security. If government borrowing is increased to maintain spending this may have impacts through inflation and greater government debt in the long-run.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Uncertain but could be substantial if an austere approach is taken. Mortality rates for the poorest 40% of the Scottish population have been increasing since 2012, and this is likely to be attributable to austerity policies. 14 Uncertain but could be substantial if austerity approach is taken. The best available evidence is that austerity regimes are associated with an increase of mortality rates by 0.7%. 15 This is entirely dependent on the government's response to lower revenues. An austere approach could have large negative consequences, particularly for low income groups, unless this was implemented through the mechanism of higher taxes on those with greater incomes and wealth. 16 Avoid economic policies which reduce funding for public services and for social security. Quarantine is associated with negative psychological effects including post-traumatic stress symptoms, though these are less in voluntary quarantine. 18 Moderate impact on mental health, disproportionately affecting those with pre-existing mental health conditions.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Coordinated outreach efforts will be required to reach vulnerable groups, especially those living alone. These will most likely make use of both online and telephone modalities.
body_text.section: Home isolation

body_text.text: Home isolation may lead to family stress and increase in family violence
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Families at greater risk include those on a low-income, at risk of substance use and with previous domestic abuse.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: In 2014-17, one in six households in Scotland (17%) with three or more children was overcrowded, compared to 9% of households with two children and 3% of households with one child. Among households with four or more children, the percentage reporting being overcrowded increased to 28%.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: (Scottish Household Survey)
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: There are about 60,000 domestic abuse incidents in Scotland every year, with young women most affected 19 . Over 2,500 children are on the child protection register 20 .
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Impact of increase in family violence and abuse would be severe for those affected.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Moderate impact on family stress for many, with severe effects for most vulnerable.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Encourage and support communities and voluntary organisations to offer support to vulnerable families.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Provide safety advice and support services for women at risk of domestic abuse.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Everyone who is home isolating People in overcrowded homes and families on lower incomes without access to private gardens are most at risk.
body_text.section: Home isolation will increase physical inactivity

body_text.text: Everyone in home isolation.
body_text.section: Home isolation will increase physical inactivity

body_text.text: Overcrowded/ low income households as above.
body_text.section: Home isolation will increase physical inactivity

body_text.text: Physical inactivity is a significant risk factor for physical and mental morbidity.
body_text.section: Home isolation will increase physical inactivity

body_text.text: Physical inactivity for a prolonged period of time could impact on both physical and mental health. Provide advice and support on health-related behaviours including substance use and gambling. Maintain and enhance existing support services. Work with providers to limit online gambling.
body_text.section: Home isolation will increase physical inactivity

body_text.text: Impacts on those at risk from addictive substances (such as heroin or alcohol), including withdrawal or resumption of use for those in recovery.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: People with active problems with addictions or in recovery A small number of people are affected by addiction to alcohol and other substances at any one time, but they typically have poor pre-existing health. For example, in SHS 1% of adults had possible alcohol dependence (based on AUDIT score)
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Rapid withdrawal from alcohol and some other substances can result in severe physical health problems, including death. People in recovery from substance issues may be at risk of relapse.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: A small number of people with addictions may experience withdrawal-related harms or are at risk of relapse. While the number of people affected are low, they are a highly vulnerable group and typically have poor pre-existing health.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Advice and support about moderating alcohol consumption.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Provide remote access to support services including Mutual Aid.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Work with community services to provide advice to avoid abrupt withdrawal.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Ensure availability of emergency facilities for managing addiction withdrawal.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Potential rise in unintended pregnancies People already in receipt of social care assistance and particularly the elderly might be particularly at risk of increased mortality if there are reductions to services, as has been observed following some austerity policies.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Large health impacts on many vulnerable people if services not maintained.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Care providers contingency planning -it is important to provide reasonable assumptions to support them, and fund any increase in cost of care
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: People may be reluctant to use health and social services for routine or emergency care People who require health or social care 260,000 admissions to acute services and 357,000 new out patient attendances per quarter in Scotland 27 Cancellation of face to face interpreting services People who require interpreters including BSL Estimated 87,000 Deaf people in the UK who use BSL as their preferred language 28 In 2011 census 62,000 people in Scotland could not speak English well and over 11,000 not at all 29 Inability to communicate may lead to inappropriate care or inability to access other essential services.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Potential for people who require interpretation to face barriers to healthcare and other services if alternatives to face to face interpreters are not available.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Ensure easy access to online or phone interpreting services
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Loss of face to face support to help vulnerable groups access social security systems (getting ID, negotiating IT systems).
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Those making use of CAB Universal Support, GP welfare Rights service in surgeries etc.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Unknown, but likely to include groups including those with limited access to IT or low IT literacy, people who are homeless and those with learning difficulties.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Increased risk of destitution for groups affected.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Existing inequalities in access to social security likely to be maintained or even increased.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Provide telephone support for particularly vulnerable groups without IT access Food access -potential disruption caused if workers in any/all parts of the supply chain were unable to work due to self-isolation or needing to care for children as schools close. Potential shortages due to panic buying.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Whole population would be affected if food supplies were disrupted People without local support or social networks may be unable to access supplies if selfisolating.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: The whole population is reliant on complex 'just in time' food supply chains.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Food is a prerequisite for health, so food shortages would have a severe impact on health.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: High impact on health if food production, distribution and supply chains are not maintained throughout the period of social distancing. High impact on individuals self isolating who do not have friends or neighbours nearby able to deliver food to them.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Prioritisation of food supply chain.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Measures to deliver food to people self isolating. Potential to use spare capacity in restaurants that have lost business.
body_text.section: Disruption to other services and supply chains

body_text.text: Essential utilities (such as water, electricity, internet etc.) Potential disruption if workers are unable to work due to self isolation or needing to care for children if schools close.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Potential shortages if energy and internet overloaded by increase demand from home workers.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: The whole population relies on provision of basic utilities.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: The number of people relying on home internet services will increase as more people work from home.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: Disruption to water and sanitation could have substantial health impacts.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: Disrupted energy supplies could cause cold-related morbidity and mortality, Loss of internet access would affect online ordering and other services, ability of many workers to continue working, and increase social isolation.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: High impacts on health if essential utilities are not functioning.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: Prioritisation of essential utilities across all the supply chains.
body_text.section: Whole population

body_text.text: Lack of availability of school provision could lead to healthcare and other essential staff being unable to work NHS and other essential staff Public sector staff, including healthcare staff, are more likely to be women and have caring responsibilities.
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Staff being unable to continue providing essential services due to the need to provide childcare may substantially threaten the capacity for continued service provision. There is a risk that grandparents or others potentially more vulnerable to coronavirus may provide childcare.
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Potentially large impact on health, as a consequence of a lack of availability of healthcare or other essential services and transmission to vulnerable groups.
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Consider alternative childcare provision arrangements 'Holiday hunger' effect for children usually reliant on free school meals during term times, plus disruption of novel programmes which aim to tackle holiday hunger Children in low income families 4.1M children were living in poverty in 2017-18 (30% of all children). 30 Over 260,000 children are registered for free school meals in Scotland 31
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Food is a prerequisite for health. A lack of food or inadequate nutritional content can impede child development and lead to both short-term and long-term physical and mental health problems.
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Impact may be substantial and will particularly affect children living in low-income households (which may already be affected by other income threats above).
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Food provision for low income families: options might include SG and local authorities make use of existing mechanisms (Best Start cards and/or the cashless cards children use to access FSM) or for the SG to bring forward the Scottish child payment and the UK Govt to adopt something similar
body_text.section: Disruption to education

body_text.text: Reduced physical activity amongst children
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: All children 23% of females and 34% of males aged 11-12 years met the guidance for physical activity in 2017, according to the SHeS.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Physical activity patterns in childhood appear to be important for establishing longterm patterns of behaviour for the rest of life. Reduced physical activity among children may therefore increase the risk of many common health conditions, such as heart disease and stroke.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Potentially moderate longer term impact of reduced physical activity which might affect deprived groups (who are less likely to have access to a garden) more.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Longer term consideration is needed for more interventions to increase physical activity, particularly targeted at disadvantaged children.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Delays to training or accreditation of health professionals may result in being unable to practice in a timely manner, exacerbating staff shortages within the health service Trainee health professionals (e.g. medical students) and existing health professionals intending to do expanded roles Approximately 6,000 medical students graduate every year in the UK, with larger numbers of student nurses and other staff completing their degree.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Newly available staff and expanding the competency of existing staff could help in support the direct pandemic response, as well as help with ensuring the continuity of routine services.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Delays to making newly trained health professional staff available to the NHS could have a moderate impact on the capacity to continue delivery of essential health services.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Ensure universities have processes to allow students to graduate on-time. Consider the potential for more junior health students to provide assistance. Ensure access to essential training in a timely manner which can be upscaled quickly to allow expanding competencies of staff e.g. online training for use of ventilators.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Education is a key determinant of health, and that the impact on children's education if schools, further and higher education closed for a significant time (or a critical time)
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: School aged children
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Adults who are receiving further and higher education
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Almost 700,000 pupils in publicly funded schools in Scotland 32
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Almost 50,000 school leavers each year 33 -these may be most severely affected by disruption.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Educational attainment is one of the best predictors of life expectancy 34 .
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: In the UK life expectancy is 4 years higher for people with the highest educational attainment compared to those with the lowest 35 . Cancellation of exams (e.g. the SQA exams which are due shortly) is likely to have the longest lasting consequences.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: The greatest impact will be on children in families with fewer resources, eg without a computer to access learning resources online. It may be less possible to continue distance delivery of further education and more vocational courses than some higher education courses.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Longer term high impact, including on socioeconomic inequalities in health.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: A diversity of outreach approaches to meet the educational needs of lowincome children will be required.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Greater investment may be required to support further education students when facilities resume normal delivery.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Suspension of public transport will reduce access to essential employment and services Provide support for active transport modes during and after the restrictions -eg road reallocation, recognise bike shops as essential service
body_text.section: Transport and Greenspace

body_text.text: Longer term reluctance to use public transport may increase private car traffic, increasing air pollution, crashes, noise and physical inactivity. Likely to be small-moderate impacts for most people, with potential for more substantial impacts for specific social groups at risk of being stigmatised.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Clear communication which facilitates community cohesion.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Stigma/discrimination/ harassment against groups thought to pose high risk of transmission People in particular ethnic groups Elderly people and those with disabilities Over 33,000 people of Chinese ethnicity in Scotland at time of 2011 census Over 1million people are aged 65+ in Scotland 8% of adults are unable to work due to a disability.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Likely to cause distress and may cause/exacerbate mental health impacts.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Stigma, discrimination and harassment against populations of people blamed in some way for the pandemic could worsen social isolation, and cause distress and mental health impacts in some.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Clear messaging that avoids stigmatising people who have Co-V or linking it to specific populations Community cohesion Whole population Whole population Positive responses by individuals and community organisations may increase community cohesion
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

body_text.text: Encourage and provide advice to enable community actions to mitigate adverse effects.
body_text.section: Affected populations Number affected (Scotland/UK) Impact severity Impact summary Recommendations

TABREF3.text: Explore whether dial a bus could continue to be used while complying with the 2m rule.

TABREF4.text: Reduction in traffic will have positive impact on carbon emissionsConsider how more remote working longer term can be achieved.Prioritise more sustainable sectors of economy for support.Social disruptionCrime -reduced policing capacity, potential for looting if shops closed, potentially rioting if supplies run out Likely to be higher risk in communities more affected by impacts above
